frameDefinitions: A Protagonist changes the overall position and posture of the body.
This frame contains perception words whose perceivers intentionally direct their attention to some entity or phenomenon in order to have a perceptual experience.
A Speaker either agrees to or refuses to engage in a Proposed_action, proposed by an Interlocutor. ''
An Agent supports their body in a particular Location.
This frame has to do with people (the Residents) residing in Locations, sometimes with a Co-resident.
A Guest stays for a time at a Location, which is not his or her permanent residence, for some Duration.
frameExamples: Smithers <t>leaned</t> forward to grab the folder on the far side.
They <t>agreed</t> to express their outrage with editorials in today's paper.
I usually <t>stay</t> with my aunt at her summer house when I go to Seville.
listRoleDefinitions: The individual whose posture changes.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> changes posture.
The <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> performs some action in order to have a perceptual experience. It is expressed as an External Argument:

<fen>Phenomenon</fen> indicates the entity or phenomenon to which the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> directs his or her attention in order to have a perceptual experience. Typically, it is expressed as an Object with verbs.
<fen>Body_part</fen> identifies the part of the body used as a sensory organ of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen>, typically expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.

<fen>Direction</fen> is used for all path-like expressions that describe how the perceiver's attention is directed during the act of perception, with the exception of those indicating the location of the <fen>Perceiver_agentive</fen> (which would be marked <fen>Location_of_perceiver</fen>)
When the activity of attempting to perceive occurs.
The general location within which the act of perception takes place.
The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the person to whom a particular action has been proposed and who responds to the request or offer made.
This is the person who proposed the <fen>Proposed_action</fen>  to the <fen>Speaker</fen> and to whom the <fen>Speaker</fen> communicates  their response.
The <fen>Proposed_action</fen> is an action that the <fen>Speaker</fen> would perform if they were to accept or refuse the request or offer.
The time interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes their verbal response concerning the proposed action.
The location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen>  gives their verbal response to the proposed action.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the individual whose body is in a particular posture.  The <fen>Agent</fen> role is generally expressed as the external argument of verbs:
A description of the position of the <fen>Agent</fen>.  The <fen>Location</fen> of the <fen>Agent</fen> is frequently expressed and generally occurs as a PP Complement:
The part of the body that provides support to the <fen>Agent</fen>'s body in the posture.
This role indicates the Time interval during which the <fen>Agent</fen> held a certain posture.
The individual(s) that reside at the <fen>Location</fen>.
The place in which somebody resides.
A person or group of people that the resident is staying with or among.
This role refers to the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Resident</fen> resides.
The <fen>Guest</fen> remains for a relatively short period of time in the <fen>Location</fen>.
The <fen>Location</fen> where the <fen>Guest</fen> spends a short amount of time.
The length of time that the <fen>Guest</fen> remains at the <fen>Location</fen>.
The <fen>Host</fen> is living at the <fen>Location</fen> on a permanent basis, and is allowing the <fen>Guest</fen> to stay there.
The time at which the temporary stay takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> indicates the larger physical setting of the temporary stay.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The waiter</fex> smelled the milk to see if it was fresh.
The waiter smelled <fex>the milk</fex> to see if it was fresh.
You should feel the water <fex>with your toes</fex> before jumping in.
The detective looked <fex>across the street</fex> at the suspect.
I stood <fex>on my heels</fex> and looked out the window
<fex>Yesterday evening</fex> he was sitting in his armchair as usual
Originally, <fex>we</fex> planned on rooming with our relatives in Reno.
Originally we planned on staying <fex>at the Hilton</fex>.
My wife and have just returned from a <fex>two day</fex> stay at Ocean Key.
You should avoid staying <fex>with old college buddies</fex> when on business trips.
<fex>In London</fex>, I stayed at a hotel.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: The Portage to San Cristobal of A.H.
Homer: A Collection of Critical Essays
Fields of Force: Fischer and Spassky in Reykjavik (1973
the Lord Weidenfeld Professorship of Comparative Literature
The Penguin Book of Modern Verse Translation
